lines.text:
[talking to other Belgian refugees about a wildflower]
Another example of the English bucolic belief - anagallis arvensis, the scarlet pimpernel. It is believed that when this flower is open, it is a sign of a proplonged spell of fine weather. It is seldom seen open in this country.

[referring to the false beard they have discovered]
Who put it there?

Someone with a great deal of intelligence, Hastings. He chose to hide it in the one place where its presence would not be remarked. But we must be even more intelligent that he does not suspect us of being intelligent at all.
Absolutely.
And there you will be invaluable, mon ami.
[last lines]
What a wonderful girl. I shall never understand women.
Thought so, yourself mon ami. Perhaps one day when this terrible war is ended, we shall work again together, and Poirot will explain it all to you.
Madame Dainty, has it ever occurred to you to organize the goods by the country of origin?
[Poirot has just pulled up in a cab outside and is waving his hands at the driver]
What on earth is he doing?
I think he's giving the driver a lesson.
May I ask what's going on?
You may ask, Madam. If you get any reply you may let me know.
[Poirot is building a house of cards]
Is this your first time in London, Poirot?
[Poirot does not answer]
Mrs. Inglethorpe must have been wealthy, with this beautiful house and Styles Court.
[Poirot still does not answer]
Are you going to be doing that all day?
I steady my nerves, that is all.
[Hastings has accepted an invitation to spend his medical leave at his friend John Cavendish's ancestral home]
I'm afraid you'll find it very quiet down here, Hastings.
My dear fellow, after the joys of France, that's just what I want.

[after finding burned evidence in a fireplace]
The fire warms but it also destroys.
Things are moving quickly, my friend - perhaps too quickly!
Hastings!
Good Lord! Monsieur Poirot.
It is indeed, mon ami Hastings.

[referring to John Cavendish's mother and her marriage to an outsider twenty years her junior]
It must be a difficult situation for you all.
Difficult? It's damnable.

[after Poirot's assertion has been proved correct]
My word, Poirot, you're the goods!

[to Hastings]
I do hope she's found him out at last. I'm sure he's a fortune hunter.
This is green.
No, it is too dark.
Good Lord!
John Cavendish, you are charged with the murder of your mother, Mrs. Emily Rose Inglethorp on Tuesday nineteenth day of June, 1917. How do you plead?
Not guilty.
I've told you before.
It's none of your business.
It is my business. Not content with carrying on this sordid affair with this woman, I now find you squandering large sums of money on her.
It's not a large sum of money. It's a loan, anyway.
No! No! My mind is made up and you need not think that any fear of scandal between husband and wife will deter me.
Why? When? There must have been something of great importance in that case, something that would have connected the murder with the crime.
But what?
That I do not know.
It's all over now.
Superintendent, I beg of you to allow me to ask of Mr. Inglethorp just one question.
So, we're back to square one then.
Not quite mon ami. We now know there is one person who did not buy the poison. Again, we have cleared away the clues manufactured, and now for the real ones.
[repeated line]
Good Lord!
